SENT.plain: Transient neonatal leukemia or transient neonatal myeloproliferative disorder is commonly associated with Down syndrome
It usually resolves spontaneously in 4-5 months
However, 25 % of patients will subsequently develop acute megakaryoblastic leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome
It has seldom been described without constitutional anomalies and is even less frequent in twins
We present three phenotypically normal patients with this disorder
One of them was diagnosed because he presented blueberry muffin syndrome
Diagnosis was guided by pathological examination of the skin lesions
The other two patients were monochorionic triplets
Their bichorionic sister presented no hematological disorders
Constitutional chromosomal abnormalities were ruled out in all three patients
They received support treatment only without chemotherapy
The clinical course was favorable with disappearance of marrow and peripheral blastosis in 4-5 months
Follow-up of 18 and 19 months has not revealed any hematological disorders
Caution must be exercised before initiating chemotherapy in these patients
We discuss the differential diagnosis with congenital leukemia and the prognostic and therapeutic implications that this entails
